questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the hospital with a fever and increasing shortness of breath. Blood cultures reveal Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), and a molecular assay identifies the presence of the mecA gene. Based on the resistance profile of the pathogen, which of the following treatment strategies would be most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Use of vancomycin, as it is the first-line treatment for MRSA infections

options.label: B
options.text: Use of β-lactam antibiotics, as the presence of the blaZ gene is likely conferring resistance to penicillin

options.label: C
options.text: Use of tetracycline, as the tetM gene would confer protection against the infection

options.label: D
options.text: Use of alternative antibiotics, as the mecA gene indicates methicillin resistance and requires an alternative treatment approach

questions.correct_answer: A. Use of vancomycin, as it is the first-line treatment for MRSA infections
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Use of vancomycin, as it is the first-line treatment for MRSA infections

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vancomycin is the first-line treatment for MRSA infections, even in the presence of the mecA gene, which confers resistance to methicillin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the effects of estrogen is/are incorrect? Estrogen increases sensitivity to oxytocin in the uterus and reduces uterine excitability. Estrogen has no role in stimulation of ductal growth in the breast Estrogen has a cardioprotective effect by inhibiting platelet activation and lowering serum cholesterol. Estrogen promotes neuroprotection by preventing apoptosis in the central nervous system.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1 and 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Statement 1. Estrogen increases sensitivity to oxytocin in the uterus and reduces uterine excitability: Incorrect. Estrogen increases both uterine excitability and sensitivity to oxytocin, which aids in uterine contractions during labor.
  • • Statement 1. Estrogen increases sensitivity to oxytocin in the uterus and reduces uterine excitability:
  • • Statement 2. Estrogen has no role in stimulation of ductal growth in the breast: Incorrect. Estrogen stimulates ductal growth in the breast, it directly enhances secondary sexual characteristics and not solely through ductal growth.
  • • Statement 2. Estrogen has no role in stimulation of ductal growth in the breast:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 3. Estrogen has a cardioprotective effect by inhibiting platelet activation and lowering serum cholesterol: Correct. Estrogen has a dual cardioprotective effect by lowering serum cholesterol levels through its actions on the liver and reducing platelet activation, thereby preventing cardiovascular disease.
  • • Statement 3. Estrogen has a cardioprotective effect by inhibiting platelet activation and lowering serum cholesterol:
  • • Statement 4. Estrogen promotes neuroprotection by preventing apoptosis in the central nervous system: Correct. Estrogen provides neuroprotection by inhibiting neuronal apoptosis, reducing the risk of neurodegenerative diseases.
  • • Statement 4. Estrogen promotes neuroprotection by preventing apoptosis in the central nervous system:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

The treatment of choice is antitubercular therapy (HRZE) along with corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
  • ➤ Tuberculous meningitis should be suspected in a patient with chronic headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness, along with CSF findings of lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose, and cobweb-like coagulum.
  • ➤ The treatment of choice is antitubercular therapy (HRZE) along with corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a chronic infection in the foot. The lesion has been present for several months and contains a yellowish purulent discharge. Upon examination, the lesion has a raised inflamed opening and is accompanied by osteolytic lesions. Based on the presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Actinomycetoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous infection involving the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones, often presenting with swelling, draining sinuses, and granules in the discharge.
  • • It can be classified into Actinomycetoma and Eumycetoma , based on the causative organism.
  • • Actinomycetoma
  • • Eumycetoma
  • • Actinomycetoma is caused by bacterial species like Nocardia, Actinomyces, and Streptomyces. Eumycetoma is caused by fungi such as Madurella and Exophiala.
  • • Actinomycetoma is caused by bacterial species like Nocardia, Actinomyces, and Streptomyces.
  • • Actinomycetoma
  • • bacterial species
  • • Eumycetoma is caused by fungi such as Madurella and Exophiala.
  • • Eumycetoma
  • • fungi
  • • The given clinical case describes a chronic foot infection with a yellowish purulent discharge, inflamed opening, and osteolytic lesions , which strongly suggests Actinomycetoma . Actinomycetoma tends to have more rapid progression , bone involvement, and produces yellow-white granules in the purulent discharge. In contrast, Eumycetoma progresses more slowly and is associated with black or white granules .
  • • chronic foot infection
  • • yellowish purulent discharge, inflamed opening, and osteolytic lesions
  • • Actinomycetoma
  • • rapid progression
  • • yellow-white granules
  • • Eumycetoma
  • • black or white granules
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Eumycetoma : Though it presents with similar chronic swelling and sinus tracts, eumycetoma is less aggressive than actinomycetoma and typically involves black or white granules in the discharge. In Bone Osteosclerotic lesions is seen.
  • • Option B. Eumycetoma
  • • less aggressive
  • • black or white granules
  • • Option C. Tuberculosis : Tuberculosis affecting the foot (tuberculous osteomyelitis) can cause chronic osteolytic lesions but does not usually present with discharging sinuses containing granules .
  • • Option C. Tuberculosis
  • • chronic osteolytic lesions
  • • discharging sinuses containing granules
  • • Option D. Leprosy : Leprosy mainly causes nerve involvement, skin patches, and sensory loss . It does not typically present with chronic purulent discharge or bone destruction in this manner.
  • • Option D. Leprosy
  • • nerve involvement, skin patches, and sensory loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Actinomycetoma is a chronic bacterial infection characterized by swelling, draining sinuses, purulent discharge containing yellow granules, and osteolytic lesions . It progresses more rapidly than Eumycetoma , which is fungal in origin and presents with black or white granules .
  • ➤ chronic bacterial infection
  • ➤ swelling, draining sinuses, purulent discharge containing yellow granules, and osteolytic lesions
  • ➤ Eumycetoma
  • ➤ black or white granules

questions.text: Match the following hormones with their primary functions or characteristics during the menstrual cycle. Column A: LH Surge Estrogen Progesterone FSH Column B: Supports the corpus luteum during the luteal phase Stimulates ovulation and release of the oocyte Stimulates follicular growth in the ovary Peaks before ovulation to support endometrial proliferation

  • ➤ LH Surge : Triggers ovulation and oocyte release from the dominant follicle.
  • ➤ Estrogen : Peaks before ovulation, supporting endometrial proliferation.
  • ➤ Progesterone : Dominates the luteal phase and supports the corpus luteum.
  • ➤ FSH : Promotes follicular growth in the ovary.

questions.text: Iron absorption primarily occurs in which part of the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duodenum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Iron is mainly absorbed in the duodenum, where dietary ferric iron (Fe³⁺) is reduced to the ferrous form (Fe²⁺) for absorption through the intestinal mucosa. This process is facilitated by the acidic environment and the presence of reducing agents like vitamin C.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Stomach: Incorrect. The stomach contributes to iron absorption by providing an acidic environment that helps convert ferric iron (Fe³⁺) into the absorbable ferrous form (Fe²⁺), but no significant absorption occurs here.
  • • Option A. Stomach:
  • • Option C. Ileum: Incorrect. The ileum is responsible for the absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts but does not play a major role in iron absorption.
  • • Option C. Ileum:
  • • Option D. Jejunum: Incorrect. While the jejunum absorbs various nutrients, including some trace elements, the majority of iron absorption takes place in the duodenum.
  • • Option D. Jejunum:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The duodenum is the primary site for iron absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Which of the following cells in the kidney are responsible for releasing adenosine in response to an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Macula densa cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Macula densa cells are specialized cells located in the thick ascending loop of Henle, near the juxtaglomerular apparatus. These cells sense changes in the sodium chloride (NaCl) concentration in the tubular fluid, which indirectly reflects the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). When there is an increase in GFR, the macula densa detects a higher NaCl concentration in the tubular fluid. In response, the macula densa releases adenosine , which acts locally to constrict the afferent arteriole, thereby reducing GFR as part of the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism .
  • • Macula densa cells are specialized cells located in the thick ascending loop of Henle, near the juxtaglomerular apparatus. These cells sense changes in the sodium chloride (NaCl) concentration in the tubular fluid, which indirectly reflects the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
  • • Macula densa cells
  • • When there is an increase in GFR, the macula densa detects a higher NaCl concentration in the tubular fluid. In response, the macula densa releases adenosine , which acts locally to constrict the afferent arteriole, thereby reducing GFR as part of the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism .
  • • adenosine
  • • tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Juxtaglomerular cells: Juxtaglomerular cells are responsible for the secretion of renin in response to a decrease in blood pressure or sympathetic stimulation. They do not release adenosine.
  • • Option A. Juxtaglomerular cells:
  • • Option C. Mesangial cells: Mesangial cells provide structural support to the glomerulus and help in modulating the filtration surface area by contracting or relaxing. They do not release adenosine.
  • • Option C. Mesangial cells:
  • • Option D. Podocytes: Podocytes are specialized cells of the visceral layer of Bowman's capsule that help maintain the filtration barrier in the glomerulus. They do not release adenosine.
  • • Option D. Podocytes:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Macula densa cells in the kidney release adenosine in response to an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) as part of the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism, which helps regulate GFR by constricting the afferent arteriole.

questions.text: Assertion: Peristalsis always moves from the oral end to the anal end of the gastrointestinal tract. Reason: The contraction segment of peristalsis is mediated by nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP).

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.

options.text: Assertion is true, but Reason is false.

  • • This statement is true . Peristalsis is a coordinated, rhythmic contraction and relaxation of smooth muscle in the gastrointestinal tract that propels food and other materials forward. The movement is unidirectional, from the oral end to the anal end, ensuring the proper progression of digestive contents.
  • • This statement is true . Peristalsis is a coordinated, rhythmic contraction and relaxation of smooth muscle in the gastrointestinal tract that propels food and other materials forward. The movement is unidirectional, from the oral end to the anal end, ensuring the proper progression of digestive contents.

  • • Reason: The contraction segment of peristalsis is mediated by nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP).

  • • This statement is false . Nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) are responsible for relaxation in the relaxation segment of peristalsis. These neurotransmitters help reduce muscle tone to allow the bolus to pass. The contraction segment of peristalsis is mediated by acetylcholine (ACh) and substance P , which cause localized contraction of the smooth muscles behind the bolus to push it forward.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with severe brain injury exhibits decerebrate posturing. According to the Herrington classification of decerebrate rigidity, which of the following is not a characteristic of this condition?

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decerebrate rigidity, according to the Herrington classification, is characterized by increased muscle tone primarily in the extensor muscles of the limbs, not all muscles of the body. This condition results from the loss of descending inhibitory signals from the brain to the spinal cord, leading to hyperactivity in motor pathways and increased discharge of γ efferent neurons.
  • ➤ Decerebrate rigidity, according to the Herrington classification, is characterized by increased muscle tone primarily in the extensor muscles of the limbs, not all muscles of the body.
  • ➤ This condition results from the loss of descending inhibitory signals from the brain to the spinal cord, leading to hyperactivity in motor pathways and increased discharge of γ efferent neurons.

questions.text: Match the following concepts with their correct descriptions. Column A: Capacitation of sperm Aspermia Superfetation Progesterone during luteal phase Column B: No ejaculate due to ejaculation failure Physiological changes enabling sperm to fertilize an oocyte Dominant hormone during the second half of the menstrual cycle Fertilization of two ova released in two different menstrual cycles
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Capacitation of sperm : Physiochemical changes in sperm make them capable of fertilizing an oocyte. Aspermia : Refers to the absence of ejaculate caused by ejaculation failure. Superfetation : Occurs when two ova are fertilized during different menstrual cycles. Progesterone during luteal phase : This hormone dominates the second half of the menstrual cycle, maintaining the uterine lining.
  • ➤ Capacitation of sperm : Physiochemical changes in sperm make them capable of fertilizing an oocyte.
  • ➤ Aspermia : Refers to the absence of ejaculate caused by ejaculation failure.
  • ➤ Superfetation : Occurs when two ova are fertilized during different menstrual cycles.
  • ➤ Progesterone during luteal phase : This hormone dominates the second half of the menstrual cycle, maintaining the uterine lining.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study to assess the accuracy of the sample mean as an estimate of the population mean. questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Standard error

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with pain and swelling in his right thumb after punching a wall. He reports that he hit the wall with a closed fist, and immediately afterward, he noticed pain at the base of his thumb along with difficulty moving it. On examination, there is significant swelling, bruising, and tenderness over the first metacarpal joint. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rolando Fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rolando fracture : Comminuted, Y- or T-shaped fracture at the base of the first metacarpal, usually due to forceful trauma like punching. Boxer's fracture : Fracture of the distal fifth metacarpal, often caused by punching. Bennett’s fracture : Fracture at the base of the first metacarpal, often with dislocation but not comminuted. Colles’ fracture : Fracture of the distal radius at the wrist, usually due to falling on an outstretched hand.
  • ➤ Rolando fracture : Comminuted, Y- or T-shaped fracture at the base of the first metacarpal, usually due to forceful trauma like punching.
  • ➤ Rolando fracture
  • ➤ Boxer's fracture : Fracture of the distal fifth metacarpal, often caused by punching.
  • ➤ Boxer's fracture
  • ➤ Bennett’s fracture : Fracture at the base of the first metacarpal, often with dislocation but not comminuted.
  • ➤ Bennett’s fracture
  • ➤ Colles’ fracture : Fracture of the distal radius at the wrist, usually due to falling on an outstretched hand.
  • ➤ Colles’ fracture

questions.text: Which of the following combinations regarding factors influencing prolactin secretion is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Pregnancy and lactation - Increase prolactin secretion

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bromocriptine - Increases prolactin secretion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist, which inhibits prolactin secretion by mimicking the action of dopamine, a natural inhibitor of prolactin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pregnancy and lactation - Increase prolactin secretion: Correct. Prolactin secretion significantly increases during pregnancy and lactation to prepare the mammary glands for milk production.
  • • Option A. Pregnancy and lactation - Increase prolactin secretion:
  • • Option B. Dopamine blockers - Increase prolactin secretion: Correct. Dopamine blockers inhibit dopamine's suppressive effect on prolactin, leading to an increase in prolactin levels.
  • • Option B. Dopamine blockers - Increase prolactin secretion:
  • • Option D. Somatostatin - Inhibits prolactin secretion: Correct. Somatostatin has an inhibitory effect on prolactin secretion.
  • • Option D. Somatostatin - Inhibits prolactin secretion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that decreases prolactin secretion, while dopamine blockers increase it.

questions.text: Match the types of grafts in Column A with their definitions in Column B: Column A: Allograft Xenograft Orthotopic graft Heterotopic graft Column B: A graft placed in a site other than its natural location. A graft taken from a donor of a different species. A graft placed in the same anatomical site as the original tissue. A graft taken from a genetically non-identical individual of the same species.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allograft : This is a graft taken from a genetically non-identical individual of the same species. Xenograft : This is a graft taken from a donor of a different species, such as porcine skin for burn patients. Orthotopic graft : A graft transplanted into the same anatomical site as the original tissue. Heterotopic graft : A graft transplanted into a site other than its natural location.
  • ➤ Allograft : This is a graft taken from a genetically non-identical individual of the same species.
  • ➤ Xenograft : This is a graft taken from a donor of a different species, such as porcine skin for burn patients.
  • ➤ Orthotopic graft : A graft transplanted into the same anatomical site as the original tissue.
  • ➤ Heterotopic graft : A graft transplanted into a site other than its natural location.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Sullivan’s Index is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: It considers both mortality and morbidity in its calculation.

options.label: C
options.text: It measures the overall disease burden in a population, including premature mortality and disability.

options.label: D
options.text: It subtracts years lived with disability from total life expectancy.

questions.correct_answer: C. It measures the overall disease burden in a population, including premature mortality and disability.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sullivan’s Index is the Life Expectancy minus Duration of disability (bed disability and inability to perform major activities). It is one of the most advanced indicators currently available to measure ‘Disability free life expectancy (DFLE)’
  • ➤ Sullivan’s Index is the Life Expectancy minus Duration of disability (bed disability and inability to perform major activities).
  • ➤ It is one of the most advanced indicators currently available to measure ‘Disability free life expectancy (DFLE)’
  • ➤ Note - Disability Adjusted Life Years [DALYs]
  • ➤ Is best measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions. It expresses years lost to premature death and years lived with disability (adjusted for its’ severity). DALYs can measure ‘both mortality and disability together’.
  • ➤ Is best measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.
  • ➤ It expresses years lost to premature death and years lived with disability (adjusted for its’ severity).
  • ➤ DALYs can measure ‘both mortality and disability together’.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with fatigue, pallor, and neurological symptoms, including tingling in his hands and feet. His blood work reveals macrocytic anemia. The physician suspects either a folate or vitamin B12 deficiency. Which of the following laboratory tests would best differentiate between these two deficiencies?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Blood level of methylmalonate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Both B12 and folate deficiencies increase homocysteine levels. Only B12 deficiency elevates methylmalonate levels. A high methylmalonate level confirms vitamin B12 deficiency, while a normal level suggests folate deficiency.
  • ➤ Both B12 and folate deficiencies increase homocysteine levels.
  • ➤ Only B12 deficiency elevates methylmalonate levels.
  • ➤ A high methylmalonate level confirms vitamin B12 deficiency, while a normal level suggests folate deficiency.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to an emergency with acute onset confusion, visual hallucinations, tremors, profuse sweating, and tachycardia. His wife reports he usually drinks 12-14 drinks daily but hasn't had alcohol for 2 days as he was trying to quit. On examination, he is disoriented, and agitated, with a BP of 160/100 mmHg. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intravenous lorazepam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%. The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity. It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.
  • ➤ Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%.
  • ➤ The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.
  • ➤ It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.

questions.text: Which of the following is the misconception about nested case-control studies?

options.label: A
options.text: Nested case-control studies are typically less costly than cohort studies because fewer participants are needed for analysis.

options.label: B
options.text: Nested case-control studies involve the collection of exposure data from participants after the outcome has occurred, making them more efficient than cohort studies.

options.label: C
options.text: Nested case-control studies require a cohort study to be already in place, which may limit their feasibility in certain settings.

options.label: D
options.text: Nested case-control studies allow for efficient analysis of rare outcomes within large cohorts, without the need for extensive participant recruitment.

questions.correct_answer: B. Nested case-control studies involve the collection of exposure data from participants after the outcome has occurred, making them more efficient than cohort studies.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a nested case-control study, exposure data is collected before the disease develops, and it is more cost-effective than cohort studies due to the use of existing cohort data.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia presents with fatigue, arthralgia, and pleuritic chest pain for the past 3 months.   • ➤ Drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE) is most commonly associated with hydralazine, procainamide, isoniazid, and sulfonamides.
  • ➤ It presents with arthralgia, serositis, and positive anti-histone antibodies. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are usually absent.

questions.text: A couple presents with a history of recurrent miscarriages and a child with developmental delay. Genetic testing reveals that the child has Prader-Willi syndrome due to a paternal deletion on chromosome 15. What is the most likely reason the child inherited this genetic condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Genomic imprinting results in the silencing of the maternal allele, making the paternal deletion manifest.

options.label: B
options.text: The child inherited two active copies of chromosome 15 from the father and mother, resulting in expression of the mutated gene.

options.label: C
options.text: Anticipation caused the gene to become more severe as it was passed down through the generations.

options.label: D
options.text: Gonadal mosaicism in the father led to a second, unaffected allele being passed on to the child.

questions.correct_answer: A. Genomic imprinting results in the silencing of the maternal allele, making the paternal deletion manifest.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genomic imprinting involves the silencing of one allele (maternal or paternal) through DNA methylation , leading to differential expression based on the parent of origin .
  • ➤ Genomic imprinting involves the silencing of one allele (maternal or paternal) through DNA methylation , leading to differential expression based on the parent of origin .
  • ➤ Genomic imprinting
  • ➤ silencing
  • ➤ DNA methylation
  • ➤ differential expression
  • ➤ parent of origin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about AMTSL are correct? Uterotonic agents should be given within 1 minute of delivery. Fundal massage is performed immediately after delivery of the baby. Controlled cord traction is an essential step. Routine fundal massage before placental delivery is mandatory.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1 and 3 only

Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Administration of uterotonic agents (e.g., oxytocin 10 IU IM or IV infusion) within 1 minute of delivery helps stimulate uterine contractions and reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • • Importance: Timely administration reduces the risk of uterine atony, which is the most common cause of PPH.
  • • Statement 3: Controlled cord traction is an essential step. (Correct)
  • • Explanation: Controlled cord traction (CCT) is an essential component of AMTSL to facilitate placental expulsion while preventing uterine inversion. Steps in CCT: One hand supports the uterus above the symphysis pubis. The cord is gently pulled downward with steady traction. If the placenta does not descend, no forceful pulling should be applied to avoid uterine inversion.
  • • Explanation: Controlled cord traction (CCT) is an essential component of AMTSL to facilitate placental expulsion while preventing uterine inversion.
  • • Steps in CCT: One hand supports the uterus above the symphysis pubis. The cord is gently pulled downward with steady traction. If the placenta does not descend, no forceful pulling should be applied to avoid uterine inversion.
  • • One hand supports the uterus above the symphysis pubis. The cord is gently pulled downward with steady traction. If the placenta does not descend, no forceful pulling should be applied to avoid uterine inversion.
  • • One hand supports the uterus above the symphysis pubis.
  • • The cord is gently pulled downward with steady traction.
  • • If the placenta does not descend, no forceful pulling should be applied to avoid uterine inversion.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 2: Fundal massage is performed immediately after delivery of the baby. (Incorrect)
  • • Explanation: Fundal massage should be performed after placental delivery, not immediately after the baby is born. Reason: If done before placental separation, it can lead to incomplete separation, increasing the risk of retained placenta and hemorrhage. Correct Practice: Fundal massage is done after placenta delivery to enhance uterine tone and prevent atony.
  • • Explanation: Fundal massage should be performed after placental delivery, not immediately after the baby is born.
  • • Reason: If done before placental separation, it can lead to incomplete separation, increasing the risk of retained placenta and hemorrhage.
  • • Correct Practice: Fundal massage is done after placenta delivery to enhance uterine tone and prevent atony.
  • • Statement 4: Routine fundal massage before placental delivery is mandatory. (Incorrect)
  • • Explanation: Fundal massage before placental delivery is not mandatory and is not part of the standard AMTSL protocol. Correct Approach: Fundal massage should only be done after placental expulsion to promote uterine contraction and reduce blood loss. Routine pre-delivery fundal massage can cause premature placental separation, increasing complications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about blood flow changes during exercise is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Renal and gastrointestinal blood flow increases to meet metabolic demands.

options.label: B
options.text: Coronary circulation decreases due to sympathetic vasoconstriction.

options.label: C
options.text: Cutaneous blood flow initially decreases and later increases to aid heat dissipation.

options.label: D
options.text: CNS blood flow significantly increases due to enhanced neural activity.

questions.correct_answer: C. Cutaneous blood flow initially decreases and later increases to aid heat dissipation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cutaneous blood flow initially decreases and later increases to aid heat dissipation.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During exercise, cutaneous blood flow is initially reduced due to sympathetic vasoconstriction as the body prioritizes blood flow to muscles. As exercise progresses and body temperature rises, cutaneous blood flow increases significantly to dissipate heat through sweat and evaporation.
  • • During exercise, cutaneous blood flow is initially reduced due to sympathetic vasoconstriction as the body prioritizes blood flow to muscles. As exercise progresses and body temperature rises, cutaneous blood flow increases significantly to dissipate heat through sweat and evaporation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Renal and gastrointestinal blood flow increases to meet metabolic demands: Incorrect. Renal and gastrointestinal blood flow decreases during exercise due to sympathetic vasoconstriction as these organs are not prioritized for oxygen delivery during physical activity.
  • • Option A. Renal and gastrointestinal blood flow increases to meet metabolic demands:
  • • Option B. Coronary circulation decreases due to sympathetic vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Coronary circulation actually increases during exercise to meet the heightened metabolic demands of the heart muscle. Sympathetic stimulation causes vasodilation in the coronary vessels.
  • • Option B. Coronary circulation decreases due to sympathetic vasoconstriction:
  • • Option D. CNS blood flow significantly increases due to enhanced neural activity: Incorrect. CNS blood flow remains relatively constant during exercise due to autoregulation, ensuring the brain maintains its function regardless of systemic changes.
  • • Option D. CNS blood flow significantly increases due to enhanced neural activity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood flow redistribution during exercise prioritizes muscles, heart, and heat dissipation while reducing flow to non-essential organs.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man, Rohan from Delhi, with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, vomiting, and confusion. His capillary blood glucose is 520 mg/dL. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following drugs should be used immediately to manage hyperglycemia in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In diabetic ketoacidosis, IV Regular insulin is the treatment of choice to rapidly lower blood glucose and correct acidosis. Early and appropriate insulin therapy is critical to prevent complications.
  • ➤ In diabetic ketoacidosis, IV Regular insulin is the treatment of choice to rapidly lower blood glucose and correct acidosis.
  • ➤ IV Regular insulin
  • ➤ Early and appropriate insulin therapy is critical to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. The histopathology of the resected gallbladder revealed Stage T1a gallbladder carcinoma. What should be the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ T1a gallbladder carcinoma is limited to the lamina propria and has an excellent prognosis following simple cholecystectomy, provided the margins are clear. No additional treatment is necessary in these cases.
  • ➤ T1a gallbladder carcinoma is limited to the lamina propria and has an excellent prognosis following simple cholecystectomy, provided the margins are clear.
  • ➤ No additional treatment is necessary in these cases.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a thyroid nodule and undergoes a fine-needle aspiration biopsy. The histology shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalks and single-layered cuboidal cells with clear nuclei. The biopsy also shows concentric calcified spherules in the stroma. Which of the following features best differentiates this from other thyroid malignancies?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psammoma bodies are a hallmark feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, helping to differentiate it from other thyroid malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can lead to Hyperphenylalaninemia? Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency Phenylalanine hydroxylase overactivity Dihydrobiopterin reductase deficiency Tyrosine hydroxylase deficiency Defect in dihydrobiopterin biosynthesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 3 and 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary causes of hyperphenylalaninemia are defects in the metabolism of phenylalanine, which can be due to deficiencies in phenylalanine hydroxylase, dihydrobiopterin reductase, or defects in dihydrobiopterin biosynthesis. Understanding these deficiencies helps in diagnosing conditions such as phenylketonuria (PKU) and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)-deficiency disorders.
  • ➤ The primary causes of hyperphenylalaninemia are defects in the metabolism of phenylalanine, which can be due to deficiencies in phenylalanine hydroxylase, dihydrobiopterin reductase, or defects in dihydrobiopterin biosynthesis.
  • ➤ Understanding these deficiencies helps in diagnosing conditions such as phenylketonuria (PKU) and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)-deficiency disorders.

questions.text: During Napoleon’s ill-fated march to Moscow, the bulk of his army faced significant losses not due to battle, but from a different cause. Which of the following diseases was responsible for the maximum casualties among Napoleon’s troops?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Typhus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During Napoleon’s march to Moscow, typhus was the leading cause of casualties, resulting in significant losses due to its rapid transmission and high mortality rate in the poor conditions the soldiers endured.
  • ➤ During Napoleon’s march to Moscow, typhus was the leading cause of casualties, resulting in significant losses due to its rapid transmission and high mortality rate in the poor conditions the soldiers endured.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with acute myeloid leukemia is undergoing induction chemotherapy. Within 48 hours, he develops nausea, vomiting, oliguria, and severe flank pain. Laboratory results reveal hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and a markedly elevated uric acid level. The oncologist prescribes a medication that rapidly converts uric acid into allantoin for renal excretion. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rasburicase is the preferred treatment for tumor lysis syndrome because it directly degrades uric acid into allantoin, preventing renal complications.
  • ➤ Rasburicase is the preferred treatment for tumor lysis syndrome because it directly degrades uric acid into allantoin, preventing renal complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man, Arjun from Bengaluru, experiences a sudden onset of severe headache, dizziness, and blurred vision while trekking at an altitude of 5000 meters in the Himalayas. Which of the following indicates the development of high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE)?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Altered mental status and ataxia are hallmarks of HACE , requiring immediate descent and medical intervention to prevent fatal complications.
  • ➤ Altered mental status and ataxia are hallmarks of HACE , requiring immediate descent and medical intervention to prevent fatal complications.
  • ➤ Altered mental status
  • ➤ ataxia
  • ➤ HACE

questions.text: A 63-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for lung cancer presents with a fever of 38.3°C (100.9°F) and erythema at the exit site of a tunnelled central venous catheter in his neck. The tunnel itself is neither tender nor red. Blood cultures are negative at 48 hours, and his neutrophil count is 1550/μL. What is the best approach to the management of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment with vancomycin and removal of catheter

options.label: C
options.text: Treatment with topical antibiotics at the catheter site

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Treatment with vancomycin alone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Localized exit site infections in tunneled central venous catheters can often be managed with systemic antibiotics (e.g., vancomycin). Catheter removal is reserved for refractory, systemic, or complicated infections.
  • ➤ Localized exit site infections in tunneled central venous catheters can often be managed with systemic antibiotics (e.g., vancomycin).
  • ➤ Catheter removal is reserved for refractory, systemic, or complicated infections.

questions.text: A clinical psychologist is developing a new scale to assess patient satisfaction with healthcare services. After administering the scale to a large sample of patients, the psychologist calculates Cronbach’s alpha to determine the underlying concept. Which of the following describes the primary focus of Cronbach’s alpha in this context?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Internal consistency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cronbach’s alpha is a measure of internal consistency, evaluating whether all items in a questionnaire or test reliably measure the same underlying construct.
  • ➤ Cronbach’s alpha is a measure of internal consistency, evaluating whether all items in a questionnaire or test reliably measure the same underlying construct.
